title: 104_hr4137
content: The Act titled "Drug-Induced Rape Prevention and Punishment Act of 1996" includes provisions related to the use of controlled substances with the intent to commit a crime of violence. The "Drug-Induced Rape Prevention and Punishment Act of 1996" amends penalties for distributing controlled substances to individuals without their knowledge with the intent to commit a crime of violence. Offenders face up to 20 years in prison and fines under title 18, United States Code. The "Drug-Induced Rape Prevention and Punishment Act of 1996" increases penalties for distributing controlled substances without consent for criminal purposes. Penalties for flunitrazepam possession and import/export violations are specifically addressed in the amendments to the Controlled Substances Act and Controlled Substances Import and Export Act. The Controlled Substances Import and Export Act is amended to exclude violations involving flunitrazepam from certain sections. The United States Sentencing Commission will review and amend sentencing guidelines for offenses related to flunitrazepam, submitting a summary and explanation to Congress. The Commission will ensure the seriousness of these offenses is considered. The United States Sentencing Commission will ensure that sentencing guidelines for flunitrazepam offenses reflect their seriousness. Increased penalties for unlawful possession of flunitrazepam include up to 3 years in prison and fines as specified in the Controlled Substances Act. The Administrator of the Drug Enforcement Administration will conduct a study on rescheduling flunitrazepam as a Schedule I controlled substance. A report with recommendations will be submitted to the Committees on the Judiciary. Additionally, an educational program for police departments is also mentioned. The Attorney General may create educational materials on the use of controlled substances in rapes and sexual assaults, disseminating them to police departments nationwide.
